content:
OpenLegislation
====================

`From the New York State Senate`

Dual BSD/GPL License. See the NYSenate licensing page http://www.nysenate.gov/Open-Source-Software-Licenses.

Open Legislation is an open source web service developed in-house by the New York State Senate to provide access to NYS legislative data including bills, resolutions, and laws. Developers can request a free key for the JSON API at http://legislation.nysenate.gov/. The JSON API is documented at http://legislation.nysenate.gov/static/docs/html/.

Updates to legislative data are distributed by the Legislative Bill drafting Commission (LBDC) in a raw, plain text format. Open Legislation parses the updates in real time and redistributes the data through the JSON API for integration with various web applications. It is developed and run using several open-source technologies and frameworks including: 

* Java 8
* Spring 4 framework
* PostgreSQL
* Elasticsearch
* AngularJS
* Tomcat

![Bill page demo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nysenate/OpenLegislation/master/src/main/webapp/static/img/bill-page.png)

Current Senate Developers
---------------------------

* Ash Islam <islam@nysenate.gov>
* Sam Stouffer <stouffer@nysenate.gov>
* Ken Zalewski <zalewski@nysenate.gov>

Past Developers
--------------------

* Nathan Freitas <nathanfreitas@gmail.com>
* Jared Williams <jared.mi.williams@gmail.com>
* Graylin Kim <kim@nysenate.gov>
* Kevin Caseiras <caseiras@nysenate.gov>

# F2025CE
Repository for storing artifacts and code related to the U.S. Army Capabilities Integration Center (ARCIC) Force 2025 Collaboration Environment (F2025CE).

# ATTUNE


## Enterprise System-of-Systems Design and Portfolio Management

The Attune enterprise tool automates our Enterprise Integration (EI) approach to visualize our clients’ entire enterprise portfolio that is fully traceable from mission capability requirements to systems and services. Attune is a highly visual web application built on open source technologies.  

To cost-effectively maintain and modernize their capabilities, organizations must identify where to make intelligent cuts and consolidation, where to develop new capabilities to fill gaps, and how to integrate what is left in ways that improve mission performance.

##### TRACING MISSION CAPABILITIES REQUIREMENTS

Attune enables you to perform enterprise design activities and determine the mission, common, and core services needed to make intelligent trade-off analyses and to do open architecture design.
- __Mission-Driven__ - Missions cross organizations so it is critical to provide full traceability and visibility of systems, activities, and requirements to mission needs. This is the foundation for optimizing capabilities and mission readiness; changes must be quantifiable via clear mission impact
- __Enterprise Perspective__ — To deliver integrated system-of-systems (SoS)
that meet mission requirements, leaders need to understand capability/system gaps and redundancies across organizational boundaries to make more informed decisions on intelligent technology injection and/or convergence. From the enterprise perspective, the government should take an “ABCD” approach when it comes to technology—adopt first, buy second, create third, and decommission fourth
- __Open Source Architecture__ —To drive out inefficiencies, the US government needs to own the architecture, the system, and the data to reduce vendor lock-in. In addition, the government needs to create modular architecture with open/interoperable, well-defined interfaces to plug in new technologies when they become available, fostering innovation
and reuse across the enterprise

Attune is a highly visual, open source web application that provides a true enterprise environment for application/ service portfolio management and enterprise
design. Attune helps you to:

- __Define and Visualize Your Portfolio__ - Understand the massive amount of
data in your enterprise portfolio through interactive and intuitive data visualizations.
Then ask:
  - What are the mission, common, and core services across my enterprise so I can make consolidation decisions?
  - Where do I have gaps that need to be addressed?

- __Trace Portfolio Relationships__ - Understand connections of program support and the relevancy to missions and capabilities, enabling impact assessment of decisions
- __Define System and Service Specifications__ - View and manage system and service
specifications across the whole enterprise. Specifications provide the blueprint for implementation
- __Quantify Your Portfolio__ - Quickly view and find what assets you have and their detailed information, identify potential gaps and duplication, and see the cost and acquisition information tied to the systems. Then ask:
  - Should I build or buy?
  - Does it make sense for me to reuse certain systems?

- __Perform Trade-Off Analysis__ - Perform what-if analysis to determine trade-offs of different courses of actions to ensure mission readiness is still maintained by different decision scenarios. For example:
  - Will I still be able to meet mission demands after making certain cuts?
  - How can I best optimize my capabilities given the current funding?

  




### Tech

Attune uses a number of open source projects to work properly:

* [Bootstrap](http://getbootstrap.com) - HTML, CSS, and JS framework for developing responsive, mobile first projects on the web
* [Cytoscape.js](http://js.cytoscape.org/) - JS library for drawing graphs 
* [D3.js](http://d3js.org/) - JavaScript library for manipulating documents based on data.
* [Inflection.js](https://code.google.com/p/inflection-js/) - Library for correctly pluralizing strings 
* [jQuery](https://jquery.com/) -HTML document traversal and manipulation, event handling, animation
* [jQuery.editable-select.js](https://github.com/indrimuska/jquery-editable-select) - Library to transform normal select element into an editable one with suggestions
* [Sortable.js](https://github.com/RubaXa/Sortable) - JS library that allows the user to rearrange list items via drag n’ drop 
* [Vis.js/vis.css](http://visjs.org/) - Timeline library 
* [Simple-sidebar.css](https://github.com/IronSummitMedia/startbootstrap-simple-sidebar) -A bootstrap friendly sidebar 
* [accounting.js](http://openexchangerates.github.io/accounting.js/) -Library to format strings/numbers to be represented as accounting strings with a currency and decimals
* [Guava](https://github.com/google/guava) - Java library used to do some arithmetic on Sets (and other data structures)
* [evo-inflector](https://github.com/atteo/evo-inflector) - Java library used to pluralize strings
* [Bootstrap Hover Dropdown](https://github.com/CWSpear/bootstrap-hover-dropdown) - Bootstrap plugin that allows dropdowns to be enabled by hover rather than click.


### Installation

For full details on how to install and use Attune, please request access to the [Booz Allen wiki page](https://collab.boozallenet.com/confluence/display/FLEX/Attune).

project_description: Prototype of core enterprise infrastructure services to address cross-cutting concerns (e.g. security, discovery, metrics, monitoring) enabling interoperability across distributed web services

input: Prototype of core enterprise infrastructure services to address cross-cutting concerns eg security discovery metrics monitoring enabling interoperability across distributed web services

content:
# Service DialTone Alpha Prototype


## Core Enterprise Infrastructure Services

To enable interoperability (sharing of data through services) agilely across multiple, distributed environment, organizations must handle several common, cross-cutting concerns such as identity and access management, service discovery, audit logging, metrics and monitoring. As well as these generic cross-cutting concerns, there are also cross-cutting concerns that are specific to the application in use such as alerting/notification, search and data discovery. Organizations spend significant amounts of time integrating vendor solutions to meet their mission needs. Each of these vendor products may handle these cross-cutting concerns in a unique, non-standard fashion. This can cost organization significant time and money to integrate this core functionality.

The Service DialTone (SDT) suite of core enterprise infrastructure services provides the core foundational "harness" to address these cross-cutting concerns that present challenges to service development and interoperability. By abstracting away these cross-cutting concerns the SDT lessens the implementation burden on developers enabling organizations and their vendors to focus more of their time on mission-specific services and applications.  

##### CROSS-CUTTING REQUIREMENTS
The SDT takes care of the cross-cutting demands common with a service development. In doing so the SDT provides core interoperability by enabling organizations to access services and share data as described in the following requirements:
- __Unanticipated User__ - Users and services may need access to mission services without a-priori knowledge and setup. This includes the explicit exchange of consumer/provider certificates as well as the population of user attributes and credentials by target services
- __Access Control__ - Access to services are granted on based on the requesting user/system attributes and the access control policy defined for the requested service
- __Runtime Discovery__ - Services should be able to deployed and discoverable by clients automatically. If a service is relocated it should be discovered automatically by clients
- __Proactive Monitoring__ - The current and past "health" of a service should be available. If a service status changes system administrators should be alerted
- __User and Usage Analysis__ - Metrics should be gathered and calculated for service performance and user activity tracking. Some common metrics are:
  - Number of Requests -  The total number of service invocations received
  - Number of Successful Requests - The number of service invocations received and processed successfully
  - Number of Unsuccessful Requests - The number of service invocations received and not processed successfully
  - Average Response Time - An average of the service response times
  - Maximum Response Time - The maximum service invocation response time
  - Last Response Time - The response time of the last service invocation
  - Uptime - The amount of time since the last known system failure
  - Status History - The history of "health" checks for a service
- __Alerting__ - Services have the ability to selectively disseminate notification of events of interest


##### CROSS-CUTTING CAPABILITIES
The SDT suite of services delivers the functionality to address the cross-cutting requirements listed above. Each of these services implement a series of design patterns based on standards adopted by industry, government and academia.
- __Identity and Access Management__ - Enables uniform authentication for users across multiple applications and provides security authorization to services and data
- __Service Discovery__ — Provides automatic discovery of services across a given network
- __Audit Logging__ — Logs details about each service call including who made the request, where from, were they granted access and the response returned. Used for metrics calculations
- __Monitoring__ — Performs "health" checks against services to determine status. A history of the service status is kept to calculate uptime and potential compare a service against a Service Level Agreement (SLA)
- __Metrics__ — Provides analytics for service usage and user activity/pattern analysis
- __Notification__ — Provides lightweight, messaging capability to enable the publishing and consuming of events/alerts


### Technology Stack
The SDT uses a number of open source projects to work properly:

* [Spring](http://projects.spring.io/spring-framework/) -General application development framework
* [Jetty](http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/) - Lightweight web server hosting for majority of services
* [PicketLink](http://picketlink.org/) - Java Library to perform XACML processing for access control 
* [OpenESM](https://www.army.mil/article/65084/Army_researchers_support_joint_experiment_to_speed_communications_using_open_source_technology) - Open source metrics/monitoring platform provided by ARMY CERDEC.
* [Apache CXF](http://cxf.apache.org/) - Framework for alerting and notification 
* [MySQL](https://www.mysql.com/) - General persistence/database storage
* [PostgrsSQL](https://www.postgresql.org/) - Used specifically for OpenESM


### Installation

For full details on how to install and use SDT, please request access to the [Booz Allen wiki page](TBD).

input: Modified Kaizen Instance to Support CyberSim Team Training CPT Environment

content:
WHAT IS THIS
====
CyberSim is an assessment platform intended for multiple uses:
- An assessment tool provided to job candidates for hiring purposes
- A post-hiring assessment tool to identify employee strengths and gaps, and
- A training tool to provide "on your own time" trainint for employees


INITIAL INSTALLATION
====

This is a keystone.js project.  
Keystone.js requires that  Node.js 0.10+ and MongoDB v2.4+ be installed.  
If you are on a Mac, we recommend using Homebrew to install those dependencies.

1. Install Node.js globally
2. Install NPM globally
3. Install MongoDB globally.  
   It's recommended you use a configuration file to set the directories where MongoDB will log and store data.
   A sample configuration file has been included in this repo as   'mongodb.conf.sample'.
4. Clone this repository into whichever directory you'd like to use for the project.
5. Install the NPM dependencies  
	$ npm install
6. Start mongodb (use the path for your config file)  
	$ mongod --config /usr/local/Cellar/mongodb/2.6.7/mongodb.conf
7. Install Gulp globally (if you like, if you don't you'll need to reference the local install whenever you run it)  
	$ npm install --global gulp  
8. Run gulp and wait for the build to finish  NOTE:  when you see "Finished 'default' after xx ms" gulp has completed executing.  It is now "watching" for file changes.
	$ gulp
9. Optional: if you want to seed your environment with development test data you can run the devseed.js script:
	$ MONGO_URL=mongodb://localhost/kaizen node devseed.js
   This will load all the updates in the test/updates directory
    In addition, a bash script has been created "reseedMongo.sh" that will handle this for you.
10. Start keystone.js  
	$ node keystone
11. Navigate to http://localhost:3000/ and observe that the site loads succesfully (hopefully)
    You can login using: 
    	username: Super Admin
    	password: pass2222
12. Note:  There are other users defined in the system when you run the devseed, they will all be
    broken, as their are being created without encryption.  Once logged in as the Super Admin,
    you can create another account with full privileges for yourself, then safely delete all
    the extraneous accounts.

ENVIRONMENTS
===

* The development server:  http://dev.boozallencybersim.com/login
    NOTE:  Currently offline

* The staging server: http://staging.boozllencybersim.com/login
    NOTE:  On stagine, you can add "?action=test" to the URL to bypass the Google 2FA
  Username:  super admin
  Password:  pass2222

USEFUL RESOURCES
===

*  Interactive mockups from the client:  http://gator4194.hostgator.com/~foamcube/inprogress/talent4sight/core_index/core.html

* Jira board (as of 2016/09/07):
https://jira.boozallencsn.com/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=52

* Confluence boards (two, as of 2016/09/07):
New:  https://confluence.usae.bah.com:8443/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=18645389
Old:  https://confluence.boozallencsn.com/display/CYB/CyberSIM


ADDING A CLIENT SIDE LIBRARY
====

Kaizen is using Bower to manage client side libraries and Require.js to manage dependencies in the browser. 
bower.json contains all the dependencies. Currently, 
the bower_components are copied to the public/lib directory via the gulp task "bower". So, to add a new library 
 do something like:
 
	1. bower install --save mylibrary
	2. gulp bower
	
Bower libraries are copied to public/lib. For development, the files will be references from there. In production, they 
are concatenated into all.js and site.min.css.

Once installed, you have to tell require how to find the library. The paths and shims are located in the
 ./common/require-config.js file. If the library is require/amd aware, then you only need to tell require 
 about the path. If not, then add a shim and tell require what it's main "export" is. 

The production build process uses the amd hierarchy to decide what scripts, and in what order to include in the
production all.js file. If your script it setup properly in require-config.js it should make its way to all.js
and into production without any additional work.

Currently, most CSS is being included, inline, in site.less. If you want to include a css file on a single page only
you will have to add it (and any of its dependencies) to the gulpfile.js package task (package-copy-tmp).
 
 
ADDING A SERVER SIDE LIBRARY
============================
npm install --save[-dev] mylibrary

 
DEPLOYMENT
====
Kaizen deployment consists of a packaged tar.gz file that contains all required dependencies to run the application in a
production environment. 

running: 
	gulp package
will create the tar.gz in the ./dist directory. 
Gulp package does the following:

	1. Runs bower
	2. creates ./common/build.json containing build versioning information
	2. minifies and concatenates ALL javascript files and libraries according to the require.js dependencies, and creates an ./public/js/all.js
	3. copies required application files to the ./tmp_package directory. See gulp task "package-copy-tmp" for the files it copies.
	4. runs npm install --production to get the node libraries we need for production
	5. creates tar.gz of tmp_package directory
This file can be copied to any server of the same platform (OS X, Windows, Linux) it was built on and executed in place. 
Running the application in production requires 4 environment variables:

	1. MONGO_URL=mongodb://username:password@1.2.3.4/kaizen
	2. NODE_ENV=production
	3. APP_BASE_URL=http://test.kaizen.surgeforward.com
	4. PORT=3000

When deploying the application on linux, it's nice to have a daemon monitor and an init.d script. 
I use the npm packages: forever and initd-forever to accomplish this.

	1. npm install forever -g
	2. initd-forever --app /home/kaizen/app/kaizen/keystone.js --env production --name kaizen
	3. I then edited the generated script: vi /etc/init.d/kaizen 
	   And added a second env variable below the line: export NODE_ENV=production 
	   
	   MONGO_URL=mongodb://kaizen:*********@localhost/kaizen
	
 	   
From there I just run: 

	service kaizen [start|stop|restart|status] 
to manage the process. The init.d script uses
forever to monitor the app and restart it if it crashes.

Once the init.d script is in place, upgarding is simply overwriting the contents of /home/kaizen/app/kaizen with a new tar.gz distribution.

# SSP Project Configuration Repository #

This repository is a project configuration repository for SSP.

# puppet-module-pf-proxy #

This module configures an Apache reverse proxy to support SSL offload and
PingFederate integration.

For more details on how PingFederate gets installed see
https://documentation.pingidentity.com/display/AIKL31/Installing+and+Configuring+the+Apache+Agent

To use, include the class, then declare a pf_proxy::vhost:

    class { "::pf_proxy":
      servername        => 'www.example.com',
      cookiedomain      => '.examples.com',
      loginhost         => 'sso.example.com',
      cookiename        => 'opentoken',
      idpid             => 'EXAMPLE_IDP',
    }

# Configuration Options #

## servername ##

The name to be used for the server, defaults to `$fqdn`.  If this
apache instance is handling SSL this must match the subject name of
the SSL certificate.

## cookiedomain ##

The domain to use for authentication cookies.  Needs to start with a period,
or be the fully-qualified hostname.  Defaults to `.$domain`.

## cookiename ##

The name of the authentication cookie.  Defaults to `opentoken`, needs to
match the cookiename in your agent config.

## filter ##

A filter setting to allow you to do SSO only on a portion of the site.
Defaults to `/` to protect everything (see `anonymous` if you want to
allow certain areas to be accessed without authentication, such as for
API endpoints).

## idpid ##

This is your Identity Provider ID, it must match the value in your
agent config.

## loginhost ##

The hostname of the PingFederate server to redirect to for
authentication.  Defaults to `sso.boozallencsn.com`, for development
hosts you might need to use `sso-dev.boozallencsn.com` instead.

## loginurl ##

This url is assembled from the `loginhost` and `idpid` values, you
shouldn't ever need to change it.

## errorurl ##

Optional.  Sets the URL to redirect to on errors.  Default is
undefined (which will show the default PingFederate error page
instead).

## cancelurl ##

Optional.  Sets the URL to redirect to when authentication is
cancelled.  Default is undefined (which will show the default
PingFederate cancel page instead).

## slourl ##

Optional.  Sets the URL to redirect to when using Single Log Out.
Default is undefined (which disables Single Log Out).

## pfbaseurl ##

Optiona. Sets 'PingFederateBaseUrl' in the Apache configuration.
Defaults to undefined to use the PingFederate defaults.  You shouldn't
ever need to set this.

## testmode ##

Enables testmode, which allows you to append ?cmd=PingStartPage to any
URL on your server and get back a test page showing the PingFederate
values that were passed to the server.  Default is `false` to disable
this option.

## loglevel ##

Set the log level for PingFederate logging.  The default level is
`warning`.

## ssl_crl, ssl_crl_path, ssl_crl_check, ssl_crl_chain ##

SSL CRL settings, you shouldn't need these in most cases.

## ssl_ca ##

The path to your SSL CA certificate.  Default is /etc/pki/tls/cert.pem.

## ssl_cert ##

The path to your ssl certificate.  Default is
`/etc/pki/tls/certs/$servername.pem`.

## ssl_key ##

The path to your ssl key.  Default is
`/etc/pki/tls/private/$servername.pem`.

## agentconfig ##

The path to the pingfederate agent-config file.  The CSN
Infrastructure team will provide you with this file when your SSO
instance is configured, you just have to put it wherever this option
says it can be found.  Default is `/etc/httpd/conf/agent-config.txt`.

## backend_port ##

The port that the application itself actually listens on.  Default is `3000`.

## redirect_port ##

If set then an apache instance will be configured on this port that just
redirects you to the https port.  Default is `80`.

## https_port ##

If set then an apache listener configured for SSL will be run on this port
default is 443.

## http_port ##

If set then an apache listener configured for http will be run on this
port.  This defaults to undefined, to disable an http listener.  You
SHOULD NOT use this except in very specific circumstances.  This is
primarily intended for SSL offload.  If you are doing SSL offload you
should set this to an HTTP port that the offload device (such as
a NetScaler) can use, but you should also restrict access so that only
that offload device can hit this port.

## verbosity ##

Set the verbosity of logging.  Defaults to `2`.

## authnprefix ##

This sets the prefix that is added to the headers that PingFederate
uses to pass information to the application.  Default value is
`PF_AUTH_`, which results in the username being in a header named
`PF_AUTH_subject` in the request that is sent by Apache to the
application.  Any other values you requested to be sent from LDAP to
PingFederate will also be sent to your application this way.

## anonymous ##

An array of strings of URL prefixes that should not be protected by
PingFederate.  This is normally used for informational pages that
don't require login or for things like API endpoints that have their
own authentication methods.  These strings will be used in Apache
<Location> blocks, so it basically has to be directory strings.

## ssloffload ##

Setting this to true will enable ssloffload support.  This is
necessary when doing SSL offload to prevent PingFederate from
attempting to redirect browsers to the `http_port`.

Setting this to true sets PingFederateApplicationScheme to https, and
sets PingFederateApplicationPort to https_port.

# Backend Configuration #

The app that you are forwarding requests to needs to be able to use
the proxy headers to authenticate the user.  These headers start with
'PF_AUTH' (unless you have changed the `$authnprefix` setting), the
username will be in `PF_AUTH_subject`

If your application is running under Apache, you can use something
like this to set the REMOTE_USER environment variable.

    RewriteCond %{HTTP:pf_auth_subject} ^(.*)$
    RewriteRule .* - [E=REMOTE_USER:%1]

## Description

Start with a one- or two-sentence summary of what the module does and/or what
problem it solves. This is your 30-second elevator pitch for your module.
Consider including OS/Puppet version it works with.

You can give more descriptive information in a second paragraph. This paragraph
should answer the questions: "What does this module *do*?" and "Why would I use
it?" If your module has a range of functionality (installation, configuration,
management, etc.), this is the time to mention it.

## Setup

### What epo_agent affects **OPTIONAL**

If it's obvious what your module touches, you can skip this section. For
example, folks can probably figure out that your mysql_instance module affects
their MySQL instances.

If there's more that they should know about, though, this is the place to mention:

* A list of files, packages, services, or operations that the module will alter,
  impact, or execute.
* Dependencies that your module automatically installs.
* Warnings or other important notices.

### Setup Requirements **OPTIONAL**

If your module requires anything extra before setting up (pluginsync enabled,

If your most recent release breaks compatibility or requires particular steps
for upgrading, you might want to include an additional "Upgrading" section
here.

## Release Notes/Contributors/Etc. **Optional**

If you aren't using changelog, put your release notes here (though you should
consider using changelog). You can also add any additional sections you feel
are necessary or important to include here. Please use the `## ` header.

# cloudbolt-sandbox-enc #

This is an External Node Classifier for Puppet, specifically for the
Prototyping Sandbox.

# Installation #

To install it:

 * Make sure you already have a puppet server intalled

 * Make a directory to hold it

    mkdir -p /etc/puppetlabs/enc
    cd /etc/puppetlabs/enc

 * Create a deploy key

    ssh-keygen -f ./enc-deploy-key -P '' -C 'ENC Deploy Key'

 * Add that deploy key to the DevOps/cloudbolt-sandbox-enc repo on GitHub

 * Add configuration to ssh to use the right key

    cat <<END >> ~/.ssh/config
    Host github-enc
      User git
      HostName github.boozallencsn.com
      IdentityFile $(pwd)/enc-deploy-key
    END

 * Clone the repo

    git clone github-enc:DevOps/cloudbolt-sandbox-enc

 * Install Repos needed for Node

    yum -y localinstall \
      http://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/5/x86_64/epel-release-5-4.noarch.rpm \

# devops-enc #

This is an External Node Classifier for Puppet, specifically for the
CSN DevOps Team.

# Installation #

To install it:

 * Make sure you already have a puppet server intalled

 * Make a directory to hold it

    mkdir -p /etc/puppetlabs/enc
    cd /etc/puppetlabs/enc

 * Create a deploy key

    ssh-keygen -f ./devops-enc-deploy-key -P '' -C 'DevOps ENC Deploy Key'

 * Add that deploy key to the DevOps/devops-enc repo on GitHub

 * Add configuration to ssh to use the right key

    cat <<END >> ~/.ssh/config
    Host github-devops-enc
      User git
      HostName github.boozallencsn.com
      IdentityFile $(pwd)/devops-enc-deploy-key
    END

 * Clone the repo

    git clone github-devops-enc:DevOps/puppet-devops-enc.git

 * Install Repos needed for Node

    yum -y localinstall \
      http://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/5/x86_64/epel-release-5-4.noarch.rpm \
      https://rpm.nodesource.com/pub_6.x/el/7/x86_64/nodesource-release-el7-1.noarch.rpm

 * Install node packages

    yum -y install gcc-c++ make nodejs

 * Install modules we need

    cd puppet-devops-enc
    npm install

 * Add this to the config in /etc/puppetlabs/puppet/puppet.conf

    [master]
    node_terminus = exec
    external_nodes = /etc/puppetlabs/enc/puppet-devops-enc/devops-enc.js

# puppet module devops-core #

This module provides core configurations for CSN systems.

Listed below are the classes that are part of this module, along with their
configuration options.

## core::dns ##

Configure DNS resolution (not supported on Windows yet).

| Parameter              | Type          | Description                   |
| ---------------------- | ------------- | ----------------------------- |
| core::dns::nameservers | Array[String] | Name servers to use           |
| core::dns::searchpath  | Array[String] | DNS Suffix Search Path        |
| core::dns::options     | Array[String] | Resolver Configuration        |

## core::firewall ##

Configures a basic setup for the hostbased firewall.  This uses the
firewall management features in the DevOps util module.

## core::monitoring ##

Configures the system to be monitored by the CSN NOC.  For Linux
machines this mans installing and configuring snmpd.  Windows isn't
supported yet.

| Parameter                     | Type          | Description         |
| ----------------------------- | ------------- | ------------------- |
| core::monitoring::communities | Array[String] | SNMP communities    |
| core::monitoring::location    | String        | SNMP Location Field |
| core::monitoring::contact     | String        | SNMP Contact Field  |

## core::ntp ##

Configure Network Time Protocol (not supported on Windows yet).

| Parameter          | Type          | Description                   |
| ------------------ | ------------- | ----------------------------- |
| core::ntp::servers | Array[String] | NTP Servers to use            |

## core::puppet ##

This class makes sure you have some basic configuration that is
applied correctly to your puppet.conf file.  It has no
user-configurable options.

## core::selinux ##

This class makes sure SELinux is enabled and configured.  It only works on
Linux systems (obviously).

| Parameter           | Type   | Description                  |
| ------------------- | ------ | ---------------------------- |
| core::selinux::mode | String | SELinux mode                 |

## core::ssh ##

This class configures some base ssh server settings.

| Parameter              | Type          | Description                   |
| ---------------------- | ------------- | ----------------------------- |
| core::ssh::idm         | Boolean       | Configure ssh for IdM         |

## core::sudo ##

This class configures a base sudo configuration.  Note that it WILL purge
any unmanaged sudo configuration, assuming that all sudo files will come
either from the Puppet manifest or from IdM.

## core::cacerts ##

This class adds default core system CA certificates. Adds trust for CSN GitHub SSL
and BAH McAfee Web Gateway. Uses pcfens/ca_cert module.

# Meta Configuration #

This module also has a couple of "meta-configuration" options that
affect how it operates.  These are normally only used for debugging.

## core::disabled (array) ##

Adding a module name from above (just the short part of the name) will
disable that class so that Puppet will not try to enforce it.  You should
only use this option if you are taking responsibility for handling the
configuration that it was intended to perform in some other way.

For example, if you are using something other than NTP to keep your clocks
in sync and you also don't
    core::disable: [ ntp ]

This parameter is merged across all lookup sources.

## core::dryrun (array) ##

Adding module names to this list when first deploying puppet on an
existing machine might be a good idea.  This will enable the `noop`
option for all the `core::*` subclasses that are listed in the array.
That way those classes will show you what they would have changed, but
not actually change anything.

This module provides utility functions for more easily building puppet
manifests.  Many of these utilities are specifically geared toward the
standard configurations provided by the CSN.

# eslint-config-ssp #

This is the SSP configuration package for
[eslint](http://eslint.org/).  This is an opinionated package, it
makes several assumptions about your code.

# Installation #

To use it, you should add all the necessary eslint packages to your
project as dev dependencies, like so:

    npm install --save-dev eslint babel-eslint eslint-plugin-import

If you have a checked-out development version of this repo, there are
two ways you can install it in your project.  You can either link it
(in which case changes you make in this repo will be immediately
reflected in your project repo) or you can install it (in that case
the contents of this repo get copied, rather than linked, into your
project, and if you make changes here, you have to install there again
to have those changes reflected.

    # To link
    npm link ../path/to/eslint-config-ssp
    # To install
    npm install ../path/to/eslint-config-ssp

## Meteor/React Install ##

If you will be using the Meteor and/or React extensions, you also need
to install these:

    # For Meteor projects:
    npm install --save-dev eslint-plugin-meteor eslint-import-resolver-meteor
    # For React projects:
    npm install --save-dev eslint-plugin-react eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y

# Project Configuration #

Then you need to create a `.eslintrc.yml` file in the root of your
project directory that contains these settings at a minimum:

```yaml
---
# Leave out whatever parts you don't need (other than core)
extends: [ ssp/core, ssp/react, ssp/meteor ]
```

This also makes it easy to add project-specific configuration in this
file as needed.  If you need specific settings for a bunch of related
files (for example, to specify additional globals for your test
scripts) you can create other `.eslintrc.yml` files in subdirectories,
and they will get merged with the ones higher up.

# ssp-app-devel #

This is the development version of the SSP app container.  The primary
difference between this app and the related apps (ssp-app-web,
ssp-app-admin, ssp-app-api) is that this one has all of the UI modules
enabled, so you can do development on the same platform for
user-facing, admin and api work).

# Getting started #

To get started, just run the `run-ssp` script:

    $ ./run-ssp

To run the test suite, use the `run-tests` script instead:

    $ ./run-tests

If you want to specify an alternate port for either script, you can
use the --port argument.  The default port for the dev server is 3000
and for the test server is 4096.

# Libraries you should be familiar with #

## Logging ##

Logging is provided by
(https://github.com/practicalmeteor/meteor-loglevel/)[practicalmeteor:loglevel].

To use logging, just call an appropriate log method with the message
or data you want to get logged:

    log.info( 'Frobnicating whatzits' );
    log.debug( 'Broken transwarp modulator!' );
    log.error( 'Unable to repel boarders!' );
    log.trace( 'Tracing the tracers' );

## Testing ##

Tests are writting in Mocha and Chai.  To run the test suite, use the
`run-tests` script.  By default it listens on port 4096, so once it's
running point a browser at http://localhost:4096/ to see the test
results.  Go to http://localhost:4096/coverage to see the test coverage
report.

* [http://mochajs.org/](Mocha)
* [http://mochajs.org/#hooks](before, beforeEach, after, afterEach)
* [http://mochajs.org/#getting-started](describe)
* [http://mochajs.org/#getting-started](it)
* [http://chaijs.com/](chai)
* [http://chaijs.com/guide/styles/#assert](assert)
* [http://chaijs.com/guide/styles/#expect](expect)
* [http://chaijs.com/guide/styles/#should](should)
* [http://chaijs.com/plugins/chai-string/](chai-string)
* [http://sinonjs.org/](sinon)
* [https://github.com/domenic/sinon-chai](sinonChai)
* [http://sinonjs.org/docs/#spies](spies)
* [http://sinonjs.org/docs#stubs](stubs)
* [https://atmospherejs.com/meteor/tinytest](Tinytest)

The chai includeStack setting is on by default, to turn it off:

    Server: Meteor.settings.chai.includeStack = false;
    Client: Meteor.settings.public.chai.includeStack = false;


### Linting ###

To run `eslint` against your code and check it against our style
guide, just install the `eslint-cli` package globally, then you can
run `eslint` from wherever you want within the repo and it will have
the correct settings.

    $ npm install -g eslint-cli
    $ eslint .

# Recommended Reading #

* http://jagi.github.io/meteor-astronomy/

# secrets #

This is a secrets retrieval module that retrieves sensitive data from
Vault.  This is what we use in the SSP project to get API keys,
passwords and other sensitive information out of Vault.

## Development Setup ##

To use this in a development environment, you have two options.  You
can either run a development instance of Vault, or you can fake it by
putting your secret information into a file and just letting the
secrets module read that.

*IMPORTANT*: NEVER check secret information into your code repositories!

### Fake (file) mode ###

In fake mode you can provide a file (.js, .json, .yml or .yaml) that
contains your secrets.  This mode should only be used for development,
as it's much less secure, and also because the file is loaded every
time you request a secret (in case the file has changed) and it is
loaded synchronously (even though it still returns a promise).

To enable fake mode, set `$SECRETS_FILE` to the path to your file:

  export SECRETS_FILE=./secrets.yaml

The data structure in this mode is very simple, it should just return
an object where the keys are paths that the program could request, and
the values are objects containing the secrets for that key.

For example, using fake information from the ldap-workers package:

    ---
    ldap/bah:
      binddn: bind_username
      password: notReallyAPassword!!

### Vault Connection ###

To setup a local development instance of Vault, first install Vault by
downloading a package from https://www.vaultproject.io/downloads.html
or from homebrew:

    $ brew install vault

In another terminal start vault in dev mode:

    $ vault server --dev

In your main terminal export a non-https VAULT_ADDR:

    $ export VAULT_ADDR='http://127.0.0.1:8200'

You don't actually need to export this for your application to work, but if you
don't include this and you try to use the Vault CLI it will fail, since it
defaults to https.

### Insert some secrets into vault ###

Now you can insert some secrets into Vault.  If you don't know how to do this,
see https://www.vaultproject.io/intro/getting-started/first-secret.html

## Development Usage ##

Using this module is very simple, it just exports a single function, which you
call with the path to the secret data that you need to retrieve.  It will
return a promise that resolves to the data you requested.

Here is an example of how to check a password against a password
stored in Vault:

    #!/usr/bin/env node
    'use strict';
    const Secrets = require( 'secrets' );

    const input = 'checkThisPasswordOutYo!';
    Secrets( 'secret/devel/check_secret' ).then( check_secret => {
      if ( input === check_secret ) {
        console.log( 'input matched stored secret' );
      } else {
        console.log( 'input did not match stored secret' );
      }
    } );

# Configuration #

There are three ways you can pass configuration to secrets:

## Environment Variables ##

Some values can be passed as environment variables:

    $ export VAULT_ADDR='http://vault:8200'
    $ export VAULT_TOKEN='xxx-token-xxx'

## Default Configuration ##

You can set values as defaults by calling secrets.config( config ).  This
will add whatever values you include to the default configuration.  For
options that can also be set from an environment variable or a file if they
are undefined in the defaults you pass in then the environment variable or
file will be used.

## Configuration Options ##

| config key | environment variable | default                         |
| ---------- | -------------------- | ------------------------------- |
| endpoint   | VAULT_ADDR           | http://localhost:8200/          |
| token      | VAULT_TOKEN          | contents of ~/.vault-token file |
| file       | SECRETS_FILE         | null                            |
| prefix     | SECRETS_PREFIX       | null                            |

# Prefixing #

Sometimes you have a tool that access a lot of different secrets under
the same prefix (for example, all the secrets for SSP Workers are
stored under `secret/ssp/workers`).  In this case you can provide a prefix
that will be automatically appended when you call the function.

## Development Prerequisites ##

You will need a gearman server and also the gearmand command-line client.
To get both on OS X with HomeBrew, do:

    $ brew install gearman

## Installing ##

a private NPM repo you might need to install the node-secrets module
separately.

    $ npm install

    # If you need to manually install secrets
    $ cd ~
    $ git clone github.boozallencsn.com:SelfServicePortal/node-secrets.git
    $ cd node-secrets
    $ npm link
    $ cd ~/test-workers
    $ npm link @ssp/secrets

## Running ##

You can run individual workers manually, or if you want to run all the
workers in this package, you can do that with pm2.

    # If you don't already have pm2 installed
    $ npm install -g pm2
    $ pm2 start ./workers.yml
# SSP Component for Slack.com

# @ssp/component #

A Component is the main UI pieces of an SSP Resource.  It's primary
responsibility is to provide an interface between the Resource
Database and the User.

The main parts of the Component are:

## [Fields](./Fields.md) ##

Fields are the schema definition of the resource.  The fields
configuration specifies what information is accessible in the
interface and what kinds of form fields are used when editing it.

## [Actions](./Actions.md) ##

Actions are the LCM functions of the resource.  These are primarily
visible to users as the options that you can select from gear menu on
a service card.

## [Faces](./Faces.md) ##

Service Cards are able to display different information in different
contexts.  The `Faces` defined for a card provide those different options.

## [Panels](./Panels.md) ##

Panels are pieces of the resource overlay that pops up when you edit
a resource configuration, or request status or billing information.
This information is provided as an accordion that overlays the main
interface, and each collapsible segment of that accordion is a Panel.

## [Roles](./Roles.md) ##

The Roles configuration of a Component provides information on how
roles for that component are managed on the service itself.  This
provides information for the team manager to allow teams to be mapped
to roles on the service.

## [Help System Content](./Help_System_Content.md) ##

Help System Content is the text of the help system.

defined in the repo.

## Using the Interface ##

## Adding a React Component ##

Each new React component you add to this repo should be self-contained -- a
[stateless function](https://facebook.github.io/react/docs/reusable-components.html#stateless-functions) if possible.

The source for the component should go into the `src` directory, with
a filename that matches the component name (see the existing ones for
more information).  In addition, each component also needs a story
defined in the `stories` directory and a test suite defined in the
`tests` directory.

The easiest way to get there is to copy an existing story and modify
it for the new component (the `Button` story is a good starting
point).

After you have created a new

## Writing Components ##

Components that go into this library should be mostly self-contained
(or at least should strive to not depend on other components outside
of this library).

# SSP DevTool #

This tool makes it easier to perform some common development tasks.
It does require a little bit of up-front setup to get the most out of
it though.

# Installation #

First, you should have a directory where you checkout all of your
project repositories.  Many of the functions performed by these tools
assume you have flat directory structure.  I used `~/ssp-dev`, but you
can use whatever directory you want.  Once you have that directory,
clone this repo there.

    mkdir ~/ssp-dev
    cd ~/ssp-dev
    git clone git@github.boozallencsn.com:SelfServicePortal/ssp-devtool.git

Then run `./bin/devtool init` and put the output from that into
your shell's configuration file.

    ./bin/ssp-devtool >> ~/.bash_profile

# Usage #

To see what options are available, run devtool with no arguments.

Here are some of the most important commands:

## devtool help ##

Show the help information, which includes a list of all the commands
you can run.

Use `devtool help <command>` to see what options are available for the
top-level commands.

## devtool package setup ##

Configures a package repository.  This command attempts to determine
if your repo is a node package then it adds some standard boilerplate
to files in the repository.

Among the things it configures are:

  * Standard test suite (mocha, chai, sinon, etc)
  * Configures eslint
  * If it detects babel is in use:
    * Sets up standard babel configuration
  * If the package name starts with `@components`:
    * Sets up standard SSP component configurations
  * If the package name starts with `@workers`:
    * Sets up standard SSP worker configurations

Make sure that any files you care about have been committed (or at
least added) to git before you run this command!  That way if you
don't like the changes it makes you can roll them back.

If you want to start using something it doesn't detect, you can include
a --add argument to specify the flag you want to set.  For example, if
you want to start using react in that package, but haven't used it before
so it doesn't get auto-detected, you can run:

    devtool package setup --add react

## devtool package check ##

Checks for some common problems in node packages.

## devtool workstation setup ##

Setup your local workstation.  Makes sure you have all the things
installed that you need installed.  Many of the other devtool commands
won't work until you have done this.

Currently this installs [Homebrew](http://brew.sh), then uses Homebrew
to install:

  * [NodeJS](http://nodejs.org)
  * [git](http://git-scm.com)
  * [gitflow](https://github.com/nvie/gitflow)

project_description: Inject SSL root certificates into Node projects

input: Inject SSL root certificates into Node projects

content:
# @ssp/root-certs #

This is a very simple package that just injects SSL root certificates into
other Node packages when you require it.  To use it just add it to your
project and then import or require it.

Important Note:  When loaded any packages that are on the list below will
get CAs injected automatically, but only if they are already loaded!  So
you either need to load them first, like this:

    import https from 'https';
    import '@ssp/root-certs';

Or you need to specifically inject the packages you want to inject:

    import rootcerts from '@ssp/root-certs';
    import https from 'https';
    rootcerts.inject( 'https' );

# Packages manipulated #

These are the only packages that currently get injected.  If you come across
others that need to be added to this list let me know and we can get them
added as well.

  - https
  - tls

# Stage Home
Administrative home of the Stage Project.  This is the place to read documentation, find or create issues, follow discussions, request support, provide feedback, and just about any other project information.

Stage is Code Named: [***Heimdall***](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heimdall_(comics)), which hints at the intent of this project.  Stage is a ***Search and Software-Oriented Data Analysis (SODA) Service*** that aims to be the window into the Enterprise InnerSource Software Development world.  Through Stage users will discover what others are doing and how well they are doing it, and, ultimately, it allows users to more easily collaborate, share, and reuse software across the enterprise and for investments and client projects.

# Cognition™ Bootstrap
The Cognition™ Bootstrap repository is used to provision an environment with the minimal capabilities required to run the Cognition™ Insights Platform

## Requirements
1. Set AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID and AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY as environment variables.
2. Requires rancher-compose command line tools (https://github.com/rancher/rancher-compose/releases) and on your PATH

## Assumptions
1. Assumes Rancher will run on port 80
2. Assumes "rancher" keypair has been setup in AWS
3. Assumes AWS IAM user has permissions to launch EC2 Instances
4. Assumes AWS Security Groups are setup to allow for communication between EC2 instances
  1. In addition to the usual HTTP traffic, the following ports are required:
    * 2376 (TCP), 4500 (UDP), 500 (UDP) for Rancher Communications
    * 24007-24008 (TCP) for Gluster Daemon
    * 49152-49155 (TCP) for GlusterFS Bricks
    * 111 (TCP and UDP) and 2049 (TCP) for Gluster port mapper
    * 38465, 38466 and 38467 (TCP) for Gluster NFS
    * 27017 (TCP) for MongoDB

## To Provision Cognition Environment
```bash
ansible-playbook provision.yml
```
## What tasks does the playbook execute?
1. Provision AWS EC2 Instances using CentOS7 Project Atomic community image
2. Deploy Latest Rancher Server (http://rancher.com/)
3. Deploy Rancher Hosts and register them with the server
4. Configure GlusterFS storage and Convoy for persistent container storage

## Notes
GlusterFS issues, need to set the following
```
--cap-add SYS_ADMIN --device /dev/fuse:/dev/fuse:rwm
```
ubuntu needs (others may be the same way)
```
--privileged
```

# :sparkles:cognition-ui-design:sparkles:

This repo contains some beginning UI design experiments taken from the Fuse AngularJS Material Design Template, originally by some peeps at [withinpixels.com](https://withinpixels.com/)

## A. Installing Prerequisites
Download and install the latest [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/en/) from its web site.
Download and install the latest [Git](https://git-scm.com/) from its web site.

Open your favorite console application (Terminal, Command Prompt etc.), run the following command and wait for it to finish:

`npm install -g bower`

Run the following command and wait for it to finish:

`npm install -g gulp`

Now you are ready to install the app!! :smile: 

## B. Installing the Dashboard
Open your favorite console application (Terminal, Command Prompt etc.), navigate into your work folder, run the following command and wait for it to finish:

`npm install`

This command will install all the required Node.js modules into the node_modules directory inside your work folder.

_Note: Installing Node.js packages may throw a lot of warnings and errors along the way. As long as the process finishes without any error notes such as "Killed", you will be fine._

Run the following command and wait it for to finish:

`bower install`

This command will install all the required bower packages into the bower_components directory inside your work folder.

And now, you are ready to run the app for the first time!!!
:boom:

## C. Running the App
While still in your work folder, run the following command in the console application:

`gulp serve`

:clap: :clap: :clap: 
And that's it!!! Gulp will take care everything and start the app. Your default browser will be opened automatically, and you will be able to navigate through the template.

content:
# ssp-app-devel #

This is the development version of the SSP app container.  The primary
difference between this app and the related apps (ssp-app-web,
ssp-app-admin, ssp-app-api) is that this one has all of the UI modules
enabled, so you can do development on the same platform for
user-facing, admin and api work).

# Getting started #

To get started, just run the `run-ssp` script:

    $ ./run-ssp

To run the test suite, use the `run-tests` script instead:

    $ ./run-tests

If you want to specify an alternate port for either script, you can
use the --port argument.  The default port for the dev server is 3000
and for the test server is 4096.

# Libraries you should be familiar with #

## Logging ##

Logging is provided by
(https://github.com/practicalmeteor/meteor-loglevel/)[practicalmeteor:loglevel].

To use logging, just call an appropriate log method with the message
or data you want to get logged:

    log.info( 'Frobnicating whatzits' );
    log.debug( 'Broken transwarp modulator!' );
    log.error( 'Unable to repel boarders!' );
    log.trace( 'Tracing the tracers' );

## Testing ##

Tests are writting in Mocha and Chai.  To run the test suite, use the
`run-tests` script.  By default it listens on port 4096, so once it's
running point a browser at http://localhost:4096/ to see the test
results.  Go to http://localhost:4096/coverage to see the test coverage
report.

* [http://mochajs.org/](Mocha)
* [http://mochajs.org/#hooks](before, beforeEach, after, afterEach)
* [http://mochajs.org/#getting-started](describe)
* [http://mochajs.org/#getting-started](it)
* [http://chaijs.com/](chai)
* [http://chaijs.com/guide/styles/#assert](assert)
* [http://chaijs.com/guide/styles/#expect](expect)
* [http://chaijs.com/guide/styles/#should](should)
* [http://chaijs.com/plugins/chai-string/](chai-string)
* [http://sinonjs.org/](sinon)
* [https://github.com/domenic/sinon-chai](sinonChai)
* [http://sinonjs.org/docs/#spies](spies)
* [http://sinonjs.org/docs#stubs](stubs)
* [https://atmospherejs.com/meteor/tinytest](Tinytest)

The chai includeStack setting is on by default, to turn it off:

    Server: Meteor.settings.chai.includeStack = false;
    Client: Meteor.settings.public.chai.includeStack = false;


### Linting ###

To run `eslint` against your code and check it against our style
guide, just install the `eslint-cli` package globally, then you can
run `eslint` from wherever you want within the repo and it will have
the correct settings.

    $ npm install -g eslint-cli
    $ eslint .

# Recommended Reading #

* http://jagi.github.io/meteor-astronomy/

# nitro

#### Table of Contents

1. [Description](#description)
1. [Setup - The basics of getting started with nitro](#setup)
    * [What nitro affects](#what-nitro-affects)
    * [Setup requirements](#setup-requirements)
    * [Beginning with nitro](#beginning-with-nitro)
1. [Usage - Configuration options and additional functionality](#usage)
1. [Reference - An under-the-hood peek at what the module is doing and how](#reference)
1. [Limitations - OS compatibility, etc.](#limitations)
1. [Development - Guide for contributing to the module](#development)

## Description

Start with a one- or two-sentence summary of what the module does and/or what
problem it solves. This is your 30-second elevator pitch for your module.
Consider including OS/Puppet version it works with.

You can give more descriptive information in a second paragraph. This paragraph
should answer the questions: "What does this module *do*?" and "Why would I use
it?" If your module has a range of functionality (installation, configuration,
management, etc.), this is the time to mention it.

## Setup

### What nitro affects **OPTIONAL**

If it's obvious what your module touches, you can skip this section. For
example, folks can probably figure out that your mysql_instance module affects
their MySQL instances.

If there's more that they should know about, though, this is the place to mention:

* A list of files, packages, services, or operations that the module will alter,
  impact, or execute.
* Dependencies that your module automatically installs.
* Warnings or other important notices.

### Setup Requirements **OPTIONAL**

If your module requires anything extra before setting up (pluginsync enabled,
etc.), mention it here.

If your most recent release breaks compatibility or requires particular steps
for upgrading, you might want to include an additional "Upgrading" section
here.

### Beginning with nitro

The very basic steps needed for a user to get the module up and running. This
can include setup steps, if necessary, or it can be an example of the most
basic use of the module.

## Usage

This section is where you describe how to customize, configure, and do the
fancy stuff with your module here. It's especially helpful if you include usage
examples and code samples for doing things with your module.

## Reference

Here, include a complete list of your module's classes, types, providers,
facts, along with the parameters for each. Users refer to this section (thus
the name "Reference") to find specific details; most users don't read it per
se.

## Limitations

This is where you list OS compatibility, version compatibility, etc. If there
are Known Issues, you might want to include them under their own heading here.

## Development

Since your module is awesome, other users will want to play with it. Let them
know what the ground rules for contributing are.

## Release Notes/Contributors/Etc. **Optional**

If you aren't using changelog, put your release notes here (though you should
consider using changelog). You can also add any additional sections you feel
are necessary or important to include here. Please use the `## ` header.

# heimdall-webapp 

This is a full stack JS web application.  The goal of the project is to promote discovery, collaboration, and reuse through the novel application of federated search and learning across software development repositories and artifacts.

## [UI](client)
- [Aurelia](http://www.aurelia.io)
- [Bootstrap](http://getbootstrap.com/)
- [HTML5](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/HTML/HTML5)
- [Sass](http://sass-lang.com/)

## Server
- [Node](http://www.nodejs.org)
- [LoopBack](http://loopback.io)

# aurelia-skeleton-navigation

## Running The App

To run the app, follow these steps.

1. Ensure that [NodeJS](http://nodejs.org/) is installed. This provides the platform on which the build tooling runs.
2. From the project folder, execute the following command:

  ```shell
  npm install
  ```
3. Ensure that [Gulp](http://gulpjs.com/) is installed globally. If you need to install it, use the following command:

  ```shell
  npm install -g gulp
  ```
  > **Note:** Gulp must be installed globally, but a local version will also be installed to ensure a compatible version is used for the project.
4. Ensure that [jspm](http://jspm.io/) is installed globally. If you need to install it, use the following command:

  ```shell
  npm install -g jspm
  ```
  > **Note:** jspm must be installed globally, but a local version will also be installed to ensure a compatible version is used for the project.

  > **Note:** jspm queries GitHub to install semver packages, but GitHub has a rate limit on anonymous API requests. It is advised that you configure jspm with your GitHub credentials in order to avoid problems. You can do this by executing `jspm registry config github` and following the prompts. If you choose to authorize jspm by an access token instead of giving your password (see GitHub `Settings > Personal Access Tokens`), `public_repo` access for the token is required.
5. Install the client-side dependencies with jspm:

  ```shell
  jspm install -y
  ```
  >**Note:** Windows users, if you experience an error of "unknown command unzip" you can solve this problem by doing `npm install -g unzip` and then re-running `jspm install`.
6. To run the app, execute the following command:

  ```shell
  gulp watch
  ```
7. Browse to [http://localhost:9000](http://localhost:9000) to see the app. You can make changes in the code found under `src` and the browser should auto-refresh itself as you save files.

> The Skeleton App uses [BrowserSync](http://www.browsersync.io/) for automated page refreshes on code/markup changes concurrently across multiple browsers. If you prefer to disable the mirroring feature set the [ghostMode option](http://www.browsersync.io/docs/options/#option-ghostMode) to false

## Running The App under Electron

#### Note:
The first five steps below are identical to the first five steps for running this app the "standard' way, using the jspm / systemjs tooling. The difference is in the command to run the app, where the standard `gulp watch` command is replaced by the sequence of two commands:

```shell
gulp build
electron index.js
```

To run the app under [Electron](http://electron.atom.io), follow these steps.

1. Install [Electron](http://electron.atom.io)

  ```shell
  npm install electron-prebuilt -g
```

2. From the project folder, execute the following command:

  ```shell
  npm install
  ```

3. Ensure that [Gulp](http://gulpjs.com/) is installed globally. If you need to install it, use the following command:

  ```shell
  npm install -g gulp
  ```
  > **Note:** Gulp must be installed globally, but a local version will also be installed to ensure a compatible version is used for the project.

4. Ensure that [jspm](http://jspm.io/) is installed globally. If you need to install it, use the following command:

  ```shell
  npm install -g jspm
  ```
  > **Note:** jspm must be installed globally, but a local version will also be installed to ensure a compatible version is used for the project.

  > **Note:** jspm queries GitHub to install semver packages, but GitHub has a rate limit on anonymous API requests. It is advised that you configure jspm with your GitHub credentials in order to avoid problems. You can do this by executing `jspm registry config github` and following the prompts. If you choose to authorize jspm by an access token instead of giving your password (see GitHub `Settings > Personal Access Tokens`), `public_repo` access for the token is required.

5. Install the client-side dependencies with jspm:

  ```shell
  jspm install -y
  ```
  >**Note:** Windows users, if you experience an error of "unknown command unzip" you can solve this problem by doing `npm install -g unzip` and then re-running `jspm install`.

6. To build the app execute the following command (this will give you a dist directory)

 ```shell
    gulp build
 ```

7. To start the app, execute the following command:

  ```shell
  electron index.js
  ```
>**Note:** If typing the command `electron index.js` is too much for you change this line in package.json from `"main": "dist/main.js",` to `"main": "index.js",`
> Then, you can invoke electron by just typing
 ```shell
   electron .
```


## Bundling
Bundling is performed by [Aurelia Bundler](http://github.com/aurelia/bundler). A gulp task is already configured for that. Use the following command to bundle the app:

  ```shell
    gulp bundle
  ```

You can also unbundle using the command bellow:

  ```shell
    gulp unbundle
  ```

To start the bundled app, execute the following command:

  ```shell
    gulp serve-bundle
  ```
#### Configuration
The configuration is done by ```bundles.js``` file.
##### Optional
Under ```options``` of ```dist/aurelia``` add ```rev: true``` to add bundle file revision/version.

## Running The Unit Tests

To run the unit tests, first ensure that you have followed the steps above in order to install all dependencies and successfully build the library. Once you have done that, proceed with these additional steps:

1. Ensure that the [Karma](http://karma-runner.github.io/) CLI is installed. If you need to install it, use the following command:

  ```shell
  npm install -g karma-cli
  ```
2. Install Aurelia libs for test visibility:

  ```shell
  jspm install aurelia-framework
  jspm install aurelia-http-client
  jspm install aurelia-router
  ```
3. You can now run the tests with this command:

  ```shell
  karma start
  ```

## Running The E2E Tests
Integration tests are performed with [Protractor](http://angular.github.io/protractor/#/).

1. Place your E2E-Tests into the folder ```test/e2e/src```
2. Install the necessary webdriver

  ```shell
  gulp webdriver-update
  ```

3. Configure the path to the webdriver by opening the file ```protractor.conf.js``` and adjusting the ```seleniumServerJar``` property. Typically its only needed to adjust the version number.

4. Make sure your app runs and is accessible

  ```shell
  gulp watch
  ```

5. In another console run the E2E-Tests

  ```shell
  gulp e2e
  ```

## Exporting bundled production version
A gulp task is already configured for that. Use the following command to export the app:

  ```shell
    gulp export
  ```
The app will be exported into ```export``` directory preserving the directory structure.
#### Configuration
The configuration is done by ```bundles.js``` file.
In addition, ```export.js``` file is available for including individual files.

# heimdall-search
The Heimdall Search subsystem that uses Elastic Search and other search and learning technologies to perform intelligent deep search against project information in either text, numeric, or code format.

# Local Dev Install
## Install Search using Docker
1. `Clone` repository
1. `Install` [Docker Engine](https://docs.docker.com/) for your specific OS
1. `Build Search Image`: `./ops/create-search-docker-image.sh`
1. `Create and Run Container`: `./ops/create-run-search-container.sh`
1. `Open a browser` to `http://localhost:9200`
1. `Stop Container` type: `docker stop stage-search`
1. `Start Container` after the initial run type: `docker start stage-search`

# Production Install
`Docker coming soon!`

1. `Be Local` to the machine you're doing the install.
1. `Run Install Scripts`: `./ops/create-search-server-driver.sh`

# Load Initial Data
`Run Data Loading` scripts `./ops/load-index-data.sh <host URL or IP> <json data file>`

# Reload Data (drops index and data)
`Run Data Loading` scripts `./ops/reload-index-data.sh <host URL or IP> <json data file>`

# labelcraft / gridiron ![Team](https://github.com/GridIron/labelcraft/blob/master/teamresources/gridiron.png) #Install Guide Building this project is made easy with Docker, the following instruction sets will get you up and running in no time. ####Install Docker Go to https://docs.docker.com/ and install docker on your computer. ####Run Build Script for entire prototype * Ensure Docker is running successfully on your machine (`Docker ps` should not return an error) * Clone the repository * cd into the `bin` folder * Run `sudo bash build.sh`. This will run front end, api, and database containers. Once all containers are running, you can put localhost:3000 in the browser to see the website. ####Run Docker Container Services Manually * Clone the repository * Go inside the project folder * `docker build -t frontend www` * `docker run -p 9000:9000 -d frontend`. In your browser, type in localhost:9000 and you will be able to see front end content. * `docker build -t database api/database/postegres` * `docker run --name pgdb -p 5432:5432 -d database` * `docker build -t api api` * `docker run -p 3000:3000 --link pgdb:db -e "RAILS_ENV=docker" -d api`
Once all containers are running, you can put localhost:3000 in the browser to see the website. #####Production Ready Concerns -- Things to consider in a production environment - Scaling: elastically growing and shrinking the computing resources required by the amount of requests coming in - Logging: take into account how logs are being stored, evaluated and acted on. - Backups: making sure you have something to roll back to when the chaos monkeys grow too strong - Monitoring: Logs, won't give you everything -- what else do you need real time information on - Security: TLS, Certs, firewalls, DoS, XSS, and more... Its a lot to take in, good thing we don't need to start from scratch, check [this out](http://shipyard-project.com/)... ###Selenium Testing As a consumer of prescription and over-the-counter drugs, I want to check drug side effects and possibly improve drug labels so that I can make informed decisions when purchasing and consuming drugs. Our main focus on testing was to make sure that all tools on the website where functional. We based our tests off our assumptions of how this application should function. * Verify you are on the correct page after a certain action * Verify that all buttons work (not related to the graph) * Verify that the following links work (at the bottom of the site) http://open.fda.gov/ https://dev.labelcraft.io:3000/documentation/ https://dev.labelcraft.io/# * Verify the capability to do multiple searches without going to the main url * Verify the user cannot search non-exisitent drugs * Verify that all the tabs work * Verify that the leadersboard updates after a form submission * Verify that the format of the form is correct, if not verify that an error message was displayed * Verify the completion of a form * Verify that the url corresponds with the tab * Verify that the correct drug name is listed on all pages after selection * Verify that the user interface doesn't break if the page resizes * Verify that the bar graph is updated after a form submission or refresh

Booz Allen DevOps Playbook (Draft)

# Labelcraft "Mystery Site" (Hackathon Edition)

## Requirement: SSH Client
For those on Windows boxes, try [GitBash](https://git-for-windows.github.io/) as a potential terminal.

## Your Ubuntu Environments / Local VMs
Each team has four Ubuntu EC2 instances. Alternatively, you're free to work using a local VirtualBox VM running Ubuntu (14.04 on our EC2s). You can get an Ubuntu .iso [here](http://www.ubuntu.com/download) and VirtualBox [here.](https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads)

- To access your machine, use the certificate you received to SSH into the machine's public IP. A list will be emailed to your team.
- Your DevOps solution may require your machines to talk to one another. Use each machine's private IP when referencing your team's other machines. To find your private IP, log into your machine and:
```shell
hostname
```
If your hostname is ip-123-45-67-89, then your private IP is 123.45.67.89.

### Example EC2 session:
```shell
# You may have to run 
chmod 0400 HackTeamX.pem 
# in terminal/GitBash first. You'll only need to do this once.
ssh -i HackTeamX.pem ubuntu@[public_ip]
```

## Duplicating Repo  
You will need [Git][git] to make a duplicate of this repository. 


- Make a bare clone of the repository  
```	
	git clone --bare https://github.com/GridIron/hackathon
```
- Push to your new repository  
	- Must create repo on github first
```	
	cd hackathon.git  
	git push --mirror https://github.com/your-username/your-new-repo
```
- Remove our temporary local repository  
```	
	cd ..  
	rm -rf hackathon.git
```
- Now you can make a clone of your new repo  
```
	git clone https://github.com/your-username/your-new-repo
```


## Building the Front End

- Install nodeJS, npm, get certificate key, and get rid of NodeJS linking confusion:
```
	sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y npm nodejs
	gpg --keyserver hkp://keys.gnupg.net --recv-keys 409B6B1796C275462A1703113804BB82D39DC0E3
	sudo ln -s /usr/bin/nodejs /usr/bin/node
```

- Install rvm 
	- If you are running this locally, you'll need to switch to GuestWifi to get rvm
	- If you are using a VM, you will need to restart your VM after changing wifi
```
	# You probably don't need rdoc and ri, so let's not...
	echo 'gem: --no-rdoc --no-ri' >> ~/.gemrc
	curl -sSL -k https://get.rvm.io | bash -s stable --rails
	source /home/$USER/.rvm/scripts/rvm (command outputted from the previous command)
```
	
- Install ruby 2.2.2  
```
	rvm install ruby-2.2.2
```

- Check ruby version, and ensure version 2.2.2 is in use
```
	ruby -v
```

- If anything other than 2.2.2 use, you can change it by running
```
	rvm use 2.2.2
```		


- If getting the `rvm is not a function error`, follow the instructions [here][rvm]


- Install and set up bower, grunt, dependencies, compass
	- Run this command to make git replace the protocol for you, this prevents trouble with git when installing dependencies (firewall issue).
```
	git config --global url."https://".insteadOf git://
```
Move to the www directory `your-repo-name/www` and run the following:
```
	sudo apt-get install -y ruby-dev
	sudo npm install -g bower grunt

	bower install
	bower install grunt-cli
	
	# npm install will take 5-10 minutes...go get coffee
	sudo npm install
	sudo npm install -g grunt-cli
	gem install compass
```

	
#### Run the front-end  
- Run this from the www directory
	- If running ubuntu on EC2, a change will need to be made in Gruntfile.js. On line 84 change 'localhost' to '0.0.0.0', keeping the quotes
```
	grunt serve	
```

- If grunt serve is not working (not hanging), and you recieve errors try the following
```
	sudo rm -rf node_modules
	sudo npm install
	sudo gem install compass
	grunt serve
```
- The webpage appears at `localhost:9000` or `your-public-ip:9000`


## Building the Database and API
```
	sudo apt-get install -y postgresql postgresql-contrib
```

- Modify the `database.yml` file located at `your-repo-name/api/config/database.yml` 
```
  	development: &default  
  	adapter: postgresql  
  	database: ads_development  
  	encoding: utf8  
  	host: localhost  
  	min_messages: warning  
  	pool: 2  
  	timeout: 5000  
  	username: postgres						*add this line  
  	password:								*add this line  
```
- Modify the `pg_hba.conf` file located at `/etc/postgresql/9.3/main/pg_hba.conf` to look like below
	- The contents you need to modify are located at/near the bottom of the file (Shift+G in vim...)
	- You **MUST** use sudo to view and edit the file contents
```
	# Database administrative login by Unix domain socket
	local   all             postgres                                peer

	# TYPE  DATABASE        USER            ADDRESS                 METHOD

	# "local" is for Unix domain socket connections only
	local   all             all                                     trust
	# IPv4 local connections:
	host    all             all             127.0.0.1/32            trust
	# IPv6 local connections:
	host    all             all             ::1/128                 trust
```
- Refresh the file for postgres by using the psql terminal as postgres user  
```
	sudo -u postgres psql
	
	select pg_reload_conf();
	\q
```

- Move to the api directory (your-repo-name/api) and run the following commands to install rake, bundler, rails, and more dependencies
```
	sudo apt-get install -y rake libpq-dev
	gem install bundler
	sudo gem install rails

* Make sure ruby version is 2.2.2 (may have switched during install) if not follow the instructions above

	bundle install
```

- Create and migrate the database  
```
  	rake db:create db:migrate  
```

- Run the api (from api directory)
	- If running ubuntu on EC2, use  `rails s -b 0.0.0.0 -p 3000` 
```
	rails s
```

# Booz Allen DevOps Playbook

## Setting Up Your Workstation

Before you follow these steps, make sure your have created an account on the Delivery server.

### Mac OSX

1. Install git
2. Install the [Chef Development Kit](https://downloads.chef.io/chef-dk)
  
  The Chef Development Kit (Chef DK) gives you the tools needed to write Chef code from your workstation. Once you install ChefDK, make sure your [system ruby](https://docs.chef.io/install_dk.html#set-system-ruby) is set as the ruby included with ChefDK.
  
3. Install the knife-push plugin
  
  ```
  chef gem install knife-push
  ```
  
4. Install the [Delivery Command Line Interface](https://s3.amazonaws.com/delivery-packages/cli/delivery-cli-latest.dmg)
  
  You'll use the Delivery Command Line Interface (Delivery CLI) to interact with Chef Delivery. If your Mac won't allow you to install 3rd party applications, go to Preferences > Security > General and there should be an option to install anyway.
  
5. Update your Delivery user with an SSH public key
  
  Start by generating an SSH key, unless you already have an SSH public key that you can use, for example, ```~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub```.
  
  ```
  ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "YOUR_EMAIL@bah.com"
  ```
  
  Copy the contents of your id_rsa.pub file. It should look similar to this:
  
  ```
  ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAAAADAQABAAACAQDa8BR/9bj5lVUfQP9Rsqon5qJMkiVm+JAtGiwnhxqgyRhk
  YLIzm6+gcifDgMOMuwZA88Ib5WNRhxjlmTseapower4rH/jAAczdp1h17xLEEbUfQfkcqiy/Drp3k1234567
  8ad234fgvdsasdfasdfR9ddNIeNvQ7OIpOCfLEPCyFz3aRRuhpM/5cySFT7bl1O44bNgfiuqRzcXFscZb03W
  PlhaPwCvL2uxaRzdrAGQmE5jzCo6nORvKoGdVDa2++def33f3xPZCo3oJ08Q9XJ2CnfJlmyNe1hwI2NOQ3yR
  bcnfSMona7ccSyHRWGs5bS//u6P0NK5AqH5jK8pg3XwtHZqLwUVy1wX0WnnJWg9IWXf32g3P4O4NJGVUeX33
  Czv32GK8YphuEweqFu/Ej7kQp1ppIxkEtrpBfMi3na0QqZlk6wwghZLa++DUfWOhGsuuBgnsocAR5rLGy+gk
  ypdie1Ydoe8qjLVZR/jKybQfQjuZOS30fZnwJhl2ZaeraPfkEXlVhK02/8PIALGfeXdt9KvQN0p5c6lRoDxq
  BqslM+1KbKKcGdlSGEsAIP9OOWBECRxlOwqlqGHtrgWKOr376dntMIy2+fFD/74tJMjRwbRzm8IGWmj6OcF6
  EvTYYO4RmISD8G+6dm1m4MlxLS53aZQWgYWvRdfNB1DAZo3h9Q== YOUR_EMAIL@bah.com
  ```
  
  Open your user profile (select Users from the drop-down menu on the upper right, then navigate to your profile) and paste the contents of your id_rsa.pub file into the large text area under Security Information that says Enter SSH Public Key, and save your profile.
  
6. Authenticate to Delivery's git server
  
  Run this command in your terminal, using your delivery username, the delivery enterprise, and the delivery server ip address. You can find the enterprise directly below your name in the top right corner.
  
  ```
  ssh -l YOUR_USERNAME@ENTERPRISE -p 8989 SERVER_IP_ADDRESS
  ```
  
  Your workstation should now be set up to start contributing.
  
### How to Contribute

1. Clone the project to your local workstation
  
  Go to the project page (select Organizations from the drop-down menu on the upper right, then navigate to Development, then DevOpsPlaybook) and copy the ```delivery clone``` command on the upper right of the page. It should look similar to this:
  
  ```
  delivery clone DevOpsPlaybook --ent=ENTERPRISE --org=ORGANIZATION --user=YOUR_USERNAME --server=SERVER_IP_ADDRESS
  ```
  
  In your terminal, create a directory for the repo wherever you choose, then navigate to that directory and run the command.
  
2. Navigate to the project directory
3. Checkout a feature branch
  
  Delivery relies on feature branches, meaning that you can not edit or submit changes for the master branch. To checkout a feature branch, run this command:
  
  ```
  git checkout -b FEATURE_BRANCH_NAME
  ```
  
4. Make your changes
5. Add and commit your changes
  
  ```
  git add -A
  git commit -m "Commit Message"
  ```
  
6. Submit your changes to delivery for review
  
  ```
  delivery review
  ```
  
  You can now watch the progress of your commit through the pipeline from the Dashboard on the Delivery server.

7. Sync the Delivery master branch and your local master branch
  
  Once your changes are approved, sync your local master branch with the delivery master:
  
  ```
  git checkout master
  git pull delivery master
  ```
  
  You can now repeat steps 1-7 for each new feature you want to develop.
